Review from Jennifer D.
Elite '12 32 friends 53 reviews
Jennifer D.
New York, NY 7/11/2012 I have been here a few times, and each time, I like it more. I like that they never let it get crazy crowded, and the fact they really keep up the "speak easy" theme. I mean, come on, you enter through a phone booth in an unassuming hot dog restaurant! It is just cool.
This is a great place to take a date, or a friend. It is fun, and different from your every day bar. I also like taking visitors here, it is an "only in New York" experience. This is probably not the best place for a loud big group.
Drinks are a bit pricey ($15 per cocktail), but delicious and strong. It is nice to sit at the bar and watch the mixologist do his thing.
Rumor has it, you can call at 3:00pm to make a reservation. I have tried this multiple times, with no luck (just a busy signal). So my recommendation is stop by before dinner/drinks, walk into the phone booth, and get on the list. They will take your phone number and call you when your up.

Brooklyn, NY 7/11/2012 700+ reviews so this might (unfortunately) get lost in the mix; however, I hope someone sees this and succeeds in accomplishing something that I never could. here's the task:
1) ask a girl on a date (first date preferable, but not necessary) 2) tell her to dress nice (set expectations) 3) make a reservation at PDT (call at 3pm on the dot kids!) 4) walk her into Crif Dogs 20 minutes before your res, 5) order cans of PBR and tell her she can have any hot dog she wants 6) (assuming she passes the test described below) act like you're walking out, walk into PDT, and bask in your sneakiness / the awesome atmosphere of taxidermy and finely-constructed cocktails.
if done correctly, I think this could be a great litmus test for a first date, right? if the girl loves the hot dog (they are amazing) and doesn't feel let down by the fact that you told her to dress up and took her to a hole-in-the-wall (or at least doesn't show it), she's a keeper. if she starts complaining... let her go and give up the res at PDT (preferably to someone walking in).
if anyone successfully completes this, please message me and let me know how it goes. good luck!
(for the opposite first-date test, see my eerily similar review for burger joint)

Cleveland, OH 7/3/2012 1 Check-in Here Love this place. My friend suggested it as we wandered around the neighborhood, but warned we'd probably have to wait even though we arrived very early in the evening. "Go in, pick up the phone and give them your number," she told me. I charged through a (rather obnoxious) party of four standing outside the phone booth doors and was immediately greeted by the hostess, didn't even have to pick up the phone.
"You have a reservation?" "No." "How many?" "Two." "You're both here?" "Yep." "Right this way."
I was floored as she led us to two bar seats (next to two other empty bar seats -- maybe it pays to act with some discretion when you arrrive at the mystical phone booth, because we're certainly not The Beautiful People, just two ladies with good manners, apparently wonderful luck and good timing).
Drinks were excellent -- a bit of a splurge at $14-$15 a glass, but most definitely worth every penny, especially when you watch the mixologist pull everything together. So artful and amazing. I can't really add much to what the other reviewers have said. If you like a good cocktail this is the place.
I had the Paddington, which was complex -- fruity, but dry, and also tart. And I also tried the Corps Reviver, a twist on the Corpse Reviver. Also delicious. Absolutely no complaints.
I'd love to come back on a return trip to the city, and while I'm sure the experience would be every bit as excellent, I'm not sure I would have such good luck breezing in again! Definitely worth giving it a shot and definitely worth a wait if you have to.

New York, NY 7/4/2012 1 Check-in Here PDT is part of Crif Dogs, Inc. (so you aren't surprised when you see this showing up on your bill).
They say reservations are very difficult so I had someone manning the phone starting at noon on the day of and we still couldn't get it because they were all booked. So we did it the wrong-but-still-acceptable way.
We had already planned a trip to Crif Dogs though so we were still in the area. Upon arrival at Crif Dogs, my sister stuck her head in the booth and "rang 'em up" by using the pay phone (which serves as a doorbell for them) and asked if they were able to accommodate a party of 7. Thankfully, they had a cancellation at 7pm (it was 6pm at the time) so we put our name down right away.
PDT isn't very large and it was a low-key experience. There aren't any drunken folks causing a ruckus and it is just a good time to catch up with everyone in your party. Not the type of place where you have to yell to get your point across at all. The drinks are all very unique and my party's agreement is that they were awesome in flavor and creativity. I ordered the Mesclun Mule (sans alcohol) and it had a slight kick to it and wasn't overbearingly sweet. I will for sure be ordering this once again next time I come here.
The customer service isn't top-notch, but still friendly. Our server was quite the looker (and impressively memorized all the drink orders w/o needing to write anything down), but seemed to be in a tiffy mood. The guy at the front was really kind and helpful though!

New York, NY 7/2/2012 1 Check-in Here I love it! Discreetly hidden behind a cute, old school phone booth in Crif Dogs is PDT. The two establishments couldn't be different!
Dark, dim and decorated with stuffed animals (not the kind little kids collect), PDT is a really cool place to chill and try some unique libations.
I had the Benton's old fashioned. Although I'm not a bourbon fan, I can't resist anything that is infused with my favorite pork product. Oh man was that sucker potent! Luckily, it had the hugest ice cube I've ever seen and as that slowly melted, the bourbon became more subtle and the drink was enjoyable. Really good smoky bacon aftertaste.
My bud got the Summer blues and sunburn...more on the girly side of the drink menu and delicious!
They also have food items on the menu from Crif Dogs that you can only order exclusively at PDT.
No reservations allowed for parties of two. Just gotta suck it up and put your name down as soon as you arrive. We were told to come as early as 6pm on a Thursday. Arrived at 6:45pm and waited almost an hour and a half to get in. So be prepared to wait!
My favorite of the speakeasies I've been to from coast to coast thus far.

Honolulu, HI 6/19/2012 2 photos 1 Check-in Here This place will fulfill your every dream of what a speakeasy is/was like back in the prohibition days - enter a narrow, hole-in-the-wall hot dog shop.... the shop in itself is a bit of a destination with a huge menu of dogs all ways (bacon-wrapped, etc..) old-school video games like Galaga and Double Dragon at the entrance and if you look to your left, an unassuming little phone booth....
Step inside and pick up the phone, a moment later you may jump out of your skin when the "wall" (door) beside you pops open and a bearded man greets you asking for your reservation! http://www.yelp.com/biz_…
Inside, it is a bar with booths, an area just as narrow as the dog shop beside it and a cocktail menu just as creative as the decor and hot dog creations. Bacon infused bourbon, I tried some blue drink with frangelico that was amazing... Honestly, it's all about the thrill of finding something "hidden".
A MUST-DO! Where else will you get such an experience?! If anything, go to play the vintage video games cause, as their sign says, they're like 84 years old in video game years, antique! http://www.yelp.com/biz_…

Call it what it is, yes it is a speakeasy...yes you do need to go in the phone booth, at crif dogs on st. marks...you know the drill. But aside from all of that, the drinks are pretty spectacular. I'm always amazed at the long columnar looking ice "columns" (not cubes, duh).
Was able to get an table last Thursday night; the crowd was pretty chill. Some locals, and some not so local who have heard of this place...even though it's called Please Don't Tell. It seems as if everyone has been telling...I meaaaaannnn. We waited about an hour for an opening; but it wasn't so bad since we managed to wait while devouring a crif dog and some pretty damn good cheese tator tots. I digress... So an hour later, and 2 blocks away, we got a call that our table was available. We finished our drinks at another bar that remains nameless (not memorable), and b-lined our way back. So if you'd like to impress some out of towners on your speakeasyness, bring them here. Or just do an impromptu drink date with some friends. Whatever you like, come to PDT!

Las Vegas, NV 6/23/2012 I've been here twice. The first time, it was relatively easy to make a reservation for a Tuesday night. We sat at the bar and had a good time watching the people on camera in the phone booth. But the drinks were just ok.
This time, it was more of a pain to make reservations, for a Monday night mind you. At one point, we got through and then the person on the other end just hung up on us. But we did manage to score reservations after calling about 100 times each. Ugh.
It's pretty cramped in there and the ceilings are low. Not for the claustrophobic. But I dig the weird taxidermy scattered about the place. Check out the jackalope by the bathrooms! Speaking of bathrooms, the doors slide. They don't pull out. That messed me up for a second. Why do the doors have handles on them if they slide?!? And the bathrooms were tiny and nasty.
I like the unique menu that you can only get in PDT but it wasn't worth all the anticipation and hype. We tried the Chang dog and Wylie dog. The Chang dog is pretty good. The kimchi was tasty. But the fried mayo on the Wylie dog just did not work. It was kind of gross. And I love wd-50! We also tried some tater tot concoction which was ok but the puddle of oil at the bottom of the container was disgusting.
Once again, the drinks were just ok. Plus don't rely on the clientele being civilized. A large table next to us was calling out for shots and being generally obnoxious. You could tell the bar staff was annoyed but they didn't do anything about it either.
The unique entrance through the phone booth was fun but it's like the weird twist in a movie. Once you know about it, it is just not much fun anymore.

Chicago, IL 6/13/2012 1 Check-in Here It's my last night in New York, a windy Monday, and meeting up an old friend. He tried setting us up with a reso at this place called...PDT? Apparently you can try calling around 3:30pm each day to try and reserve a table. Unfortunately by the time he had free time at 4:00 all the tables were already scooped up. Guess we were out of luck.
Then again, it was just him, my girlfriend and I. Apparently you can sit at the bar with a party of 3 or fewer. Worth a shot...
We walked into a popping restaurant called Crif Dogs and checked in with the phone booth. Even though we couldn't get a table, we were seated at the bar inside after about half an hour.
Few things to know about Please Don't Tell:
1) Yes, walking into a secret wall behind a phone booth is pretty much the coolest thing in the world.
2) Expect it to be crowded. We couldn't get a reservation, then waited half an hour on a Monday. I shudder to think the wait times on a weekend.
3) Ok, there are some house rules, but this is pretty common at speakeasies. When we went though it wasn't so packed and they didn't care as much.
4) You can order food from Crif Dogs - and it's not half bad! In fact, they serve up some of the best cheese fries I've ever had. Not a bad pairing with my $15 drink.
Yeah, the drinks are pricey, but that's to be expected. The drinks are delicately crafted and the ones we tried were delicious - and strong. Maybe we shouldn't have spent our half hour waiting at a different bar drinking.
If you get a chance, go. PDT may be my favorite bar in NYC, and one of the highlights of my trip - even if just for one drink.

Manhattan, NY 6/14/2012 We were lucky enough to skip the reservation rigmarole thanks to a friend who had to back out of hers at the last minute.
The novelty of stepping in the phone booth, dialing the rotary phone, and watching the tufted black door swing open is pretty cool the first time. But then you're greeted by the progeny of Amy Winehouse and Lady Gaga, aka the hostess who sincerely believes she has the most difficult job in the world and "Jeez, just hold on a minute, I'm cleaning your table!"
Inside, you'll find a lot of decorative taxidermy. One particular bear at the end of the bar provides the perfect dramatic backdrop for the more theatrically inclined.
I seriously considered the bacon infused bourbon (described as having a smoky aftertaste) but was glad I went with the Rosemary Society recommended by our suspenders-wearing waiter.
Don't use the bathroom unless you really need to go. There's barely enough room to get your business done.

Los Angeles, CA 6/23/2012 This place is amazing. From its alluring atmosphere and tastefully strong mixed drinks, this place has got me hooked. I came in to the unassuming hot dog restaurant where my friend led me to a phone booth. As I pondered why the heck we were standing next to this phone booth he gets inside and makes a call. Suddenly, I realized that this phone booth is no oridinary phone booth, but it opens up on the other side allowing people to enter and exit from the bar. One girl in the hot dog restaurant was absolutely confused as she saw people leaving from the telephone booth! I absolutely loved the concept, and it's just one of those places where you have to experience it for yourself. The dim interior created a romantic, yet mysterious atmosphere where we ordered our craftily made drinks. Despite the appearance of a mixed drink, I was taken aback at how smooth it was, give most of the drinks range from $15-18 a pop. However, one or two drinks will sure to get you buzzed/tipsy from the way they make it at this bar.
We ordered the tater tots, which were absolutely delicious! Especially when you're drinking. I guess everything tastes a better when you're enjoying drinks and eating. However, these tater tots were crispy to very end! I was very impressed at how they managed to make it so delicious despite the fact that they were only tater tots. The crif dog was quite savory and paired wonderfully with our evening at the bar. Loved this place, and I highly suggest it for those seeking to venture out and try something different than the usual bar/lounge.

New York, NY 6/4/2012 I had always wanted to try out this place, and Friday night I finally got my chance. Three of us went with a friend who had been once before. She had called right at 3PM and got us a reservation for 10PM.
When we stepped into Crif Dogs, there was a line of people to the phone booth. My friend kept telling us to look away so the secret would not be spoiled, but annoyingly there were too many people without reservations trying to get in that there was no way not to notice. At one point the girl in front of us had a 5-minute long discussion with the guy in PDT with the door in the phone booth wide open. So there goes the surprise. I still wanted to try the phone call thing, but as soon as we picked up the phone, the guy opened door letting us in.
The atmosphere was cool - I can definitely see it straight out of the Prohibition Era. The servers and bartenders were all dressed the part too. Definitely not the type of place you'd mingle; more of a place to just enjoy your own company.
We were put in the back booth, which seemed nice and secluded until we realized we were right next to the two bathrooms. I'm not sure, but I swear at least 20 people used the bathroom during our one hour there. The place barely held 30 people, so it's like everyone decided to go to the bathroom right after we arrived. A couple of oblivious folks even left the bathroom door wide open.
I ordered the Mezcal Mule. I liked it. It had so many different flavors and was not too spicy. My friends enjoyed their drinks too (Jade Fizz and Paddington?). It seems like a place for a true drink connessieur, but since I am not, the $15 did seem pricey. For a speakeasy with more of a "mingling" sort of atmosphere, I'd go to the Back Room.

Manhattan, NY 2/11/2012 1 Check-in Here **Spoiler Alert! This review is down and dirty and doesn't leave anything to chance. Don't read it if you want a surprise. But seriously. After 600 reviews, a million bar-blog posts and a spot on the Travel Channel, what's really left to be surprised about?
I know you're not reading this review to decide whether you actually should go to PDT or not. You already have your mind made up there.
So why don't I spend my time giving you the information that you're likely looking for.
Do you really need to call ahead? Does it really take 20 minutes for the phone to pick up? Do you really need to wait an hour to get in? Are the hot dogs that good? How about the drinks? And the price? All that and more to be revealed, in...the....least.......ground-breaking...........­.....Yelp....................review...in history!
1. Yes. You need to call ahead at 3 pm the day you plan on going. Not the day before. Not a week before. Not an hour before. But at 3 pm, the DAY you want to go.
2. Yes. It will take about 20 minutes (or upwards of 50 dial-in attempts) to actually get through. Don't give up! Keep trying! And another hint: even once the phone connected and started ringing through (I must have looked like an idiot walking down 10th avenue jumping up and down like I just won the lottery) it took a good 10-15 rings before they finally picked up with a simple, inconspicuous: "PDT".
3. Make sure you know how many people will be in your group and what time you want a table. If you want bar seating, request it. Otherwise, they fit you in wherever a table opens around your reservation time. And because of the one-in, one-out style exchange, every seat is accounted for, and there is no changing of situations once you arrive. We found that out the hard way. More later.
4. No, it doesn't take an hour to get in - when you have a reservation. If you simply decide to walk in, on a whim, then yes, you likely will need to wait, anywhere from 15 minutes to upwards of a few hours, depending on how busy it is and how many reservations are already made for that evening. We went at 1 am on a Friday night in February - translation: minimal tourists and people. There was absolutely no line. Nada. Zilch. Zippo. Non-existent! I could imagine, however, that at 11 pm on a Saturday in June, you might have a completely different experience.
5. The hot dogs were good, but they didn't blow my mind. It could have been that I was drunk. It could have been that I don't think I like kimchi, and I ordered the Chang Dog. I couldn't tell you. But I'd say they're worth trying, especially if you're already there, silly!
6. Drinks - outstanding. I wish I had more money (and wasn't already so deep in) when we were there - I would have sampled one of everything! Highly recommend going if you enjoy mixed drinks. A must do. Please don't go here and order a beer or wine. Please. Unless you must. But don't. Really. Don't. Okay, okay! Order a beer, dammit! I'm not going to stop you. But I'll have my cocktail, and drink it, too!
7. Bring the credit card. They both accept it, and you'll need it. $15 a pop for the cocktaily-confections. Laid down a $100 bill with four drinks, four dogs and a side of cheese tots. That's before tip, mind you.
8. How to get in? Walk into Crif Dogs. Immediately on the left hand side in a door. Yup, that one. Open it. Step in. Pick up the phone. Dial a number. ONCE. Hang up. Wait for them to slide the door open and proceed.
9. Last thoughts: plan ahead, unless you're flying solo. In that case, you're likely to get in rather quickly, as evidenced by our single friend who decided to join us. We had a reservation for three, she had nothing. She hopped in line and dialed in after us, and ended up only having to wait about 10 minutes before she was seated at the bar. Then, the host was nice enough to switch us to larger table to accommodate all four in our group. But not without chastising me for not giving them a heads up. Hence, plan ahead and call if there are changes. They really do have the seating thing down to a T.
I would definitely go back again with a group of friends who haven't been yet. I would definitely bring out of towners or someone you're looking to impress or "wow" with an off-the-beaten path kind of experience. Worth doing at least once!
10. For good measure. Had to have a 10. I'll leave the decor, music and overall ambiance to you to experience. Sometimes, it's nice to be surprised by at least something!

Doug's Kansai Kick, made with Yamazaki 12 (all the rage these days), lemon and ginger, was spot-on too, while the Shark and Twenty Butt [something] were more miss than hit. The Shark was beat blue and too chock full of Curacao, and the scotch in the Twenty Butt [something] was hardly tamed, unlike in the Penicillin, one of our favorite cocktails. You may have noticed, but we've been spoiled with regards to premium cocktails these days, and two out of four 'ain't bad-but when you're paying $15 a drink, each one needs to deliver.
Six different hot dogs are served from the kitchen next door through a (hilarious) tiny square hole in the wall behind the bar at $6 a pop, and the crunchy Jersey-style dogs actually pair surprisingly well with the bold ingredients in these designer cocktails. Sunglassed (?) taxidermy and plenty of young, beautiful people provide visual fodder, and the bartender and hostess were both efficient and friendly. If you like hot dogs and haute cocktails, or if you're in the East Village and need to impress some people, PDT might be the perfect spot. Just take the whole experience with a grain of salt. This is, after all, a speakeasy cocktail bar affixed to a f*cking hot dog shop by a faux phone booth. And it's called "Please Don't Tell" but they have a f*cking website. C'mon, people.
